revisions.rev:
{{2000s in music (UK)}} The [[UK Singles Chart]] is a [[record chart]] compiled by [[The Official Charts Company]] (OCC) on behalf of the British record industry. The chart week runs from Sunday to Saturday, with the top 40 singles being broadcast on [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[BBC Radio 1#The Radio 1 Chart Show|Chart Show]] each Sunday. Until the end of 2004 the chart was based entirely on sales of physical singles from retail outlets, at which point legal [[music downloads]] were included in the compilation of the chart.<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Guinness Book of British Hit Singles & Albums|Guinness World Records: British Hit Singles and Albums]] (18th edition)|first=David|last=Roberts|year=2005|isbn=1-904994-00-8|pages=14|publisher=[[HiT Entertainment|Guinness World Records Limited]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/3196892.stm |title=New singles formats to save the charts |work=[[BBC News]]|date=16 October 2003 |accessdate=21 February 2010}}</ref>
The list below shows all the singles that appeared in the Top 10 of the [[UK Singles Chart]] during [[2000 in British music|2000]], including songs in the top 10 that peaked in 1999 and 2001. The date in the "Top 10 Entry Date" column is the date that the single entered the top 10 for the first time. Around singles charted in the top 10 during 2000, with of these reaching their peak that year. singles from 1999 remained in the top 10 for several weeks at the beginning of the year.
==Top 10 singles== {| Class="wikitable" !Symbol !Meaning |- |bgcolor=lightblue|â¡ |Single peaked in 1999 but still in chart in 2000. |- |'''Entered''' |The date that the song first appeared in the chart. |- |'''Peak''' |Highest position that the song reached in the UK Singles Chart. |}
[[File:Craig-David 2008.jpg|thumb|right|150px|"[[Fill Me In]]" was the first of two number-one singles that year for Craig David, in March. "[[7 Days (Craig David song)|7 Days]] repeated the success in July.]] [[File:Nicko McBrain 2.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Heavy-metal music|Heavy-metal group]] group [[Iron Maiden]] (drummer [[Nicko McBrain]] pictured) charted at number nine in May with "[[The Wicker Man (song)|The Wicker Man]]".]] [[File:Darude@ElSalvador-port.JPG|thumb|right|150px|[[Darude]]'s song "[[Sandstorm (song)|Sandstorm]]" was an international club hit. In the UK it reached number three in June.]] [[File:BahaMenJun10.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Baha Men]] became one-hit wonders when their single "[[Who Let the Dogs Out]]" reached number two in October.]]

'''Notes:''' *{{note label|Chart date|A|}} *{{note label|Deejay|B|}} "Back In My Life" slipped to number eleven on 19/12/1999 for one week before returning to the top 10. *{{note label|Orbit|C|}} "Barber's Adagio for Strings" re-entered the top 10 on 9/1 for two weeks. *{{note label|Len|D|}} "Steal My Sunshine" re-entered the top 10 on 9/1 for two weeks. *{{note label|Lennon|E|}} "Imagine" spent four weeks at number one in 1981. *{{note label|Madison|F|}} "Don't Call Me Baby" peaked at number 30 in 1999. *{{note label|Sonique|G|}} "It Feels So Good" peaked at number 26 in 1998. *{{note label|Frankie|H|}} "The Power of Love" spent one week at number one in 1984. *{{note label|Delerium|I|}} The original version of "Silence" (without Sarah McLachlan) peaked at number 73 in 1999. *{{note label|Public|J|}} "Operation Blade" slipped to number eleven on 24/12 for one week before returning to the top 10. *{{note label|Spell|K|}} "I Put a Spell on You" peaked at number 36 in 1998. *{{note label|Bob|L|}} Bob the Builder was voiced by [[Neil Morrissey]] *{{note label|Britney|M|}} "Stronger" returned to the top 10 on 31/12 for one week.
